Wall Street economists polled by Reuters expect the world’s biggest developed economy to have added 180,000 jobs last month with wage growth steady at a 3.4 per cent year on year pace.

Analysts broadly see the US labour market as strong with low unemployment and wage growth having picked up from post-crisis lows. However, traders will be looking for signs of how the broader economy is faring amid a bout of mixed economic data that have contributed to a more dovish stance from Federal Reserve policymakers.

Target goes from 470p to .............. 80p,

BE11:20am

Do not expect a market tailwind in the short term: The estate agents have
endured a challenging past few years, suffering as the changing affordability
dynamics in the UK housing market resulted in a contracting fee pool as the
secondary housing market stagnated. Alongside general market weakness, the emergence of the online/hybrid model has placed additional pressure on fees, further reducing the addressable market. We do not anticipate a material reversal of these fortunes in the short term, and forecast the transactional fee pool to continue to decline by 1% pa, as continued house price inflation is offset by fee pressure and falling existing home transactions.

BE11:21am

While the tenant fee ban will
have a material impact on profitability in 2019 and 2020, this is largely known and
the change could be a material tailwind in the medium term, acting as a catalyst
for consolidation. We understand lettings fees account for the vast majority of
profits for many independent agencies, and believe the corporate sector is well
placed to purchase and integrate lettings books onto their existing platforms, increasing the proportion of their revenues generated from recurring activities. Outside of the consolidation story, we expect the lettings fee pool to grow by c7% pa, as the private rented sector continues its structural growth trajectory and rents rise in line with wages. Furthermore, as the market continues to grow, we
anticipate further regulation, which will drive agency penetration in the private rented sector (PRS). Currently, just under 50% of landlords use an agent and choose to manage their property themselves. We estimate that for every 1% increase in agency penetration, the fee pool could increase by c2%.

SupposeToBeWorking... Morning
11:21 am
BE11:21am

So, yeah, that's the sector stuff. More importantly they've noticed that Purplebricks doesn't have enough cash.

BE11:22am

The "Icarus of Solihull", they call it.

casapinos I love purplebricks- they didn't sell my house but have contributed to a sharp fall in local estate agents fees!
BE11:23am

Purplebricks is suffering from the double challenge of slowing growth in its core UK market and deteriorating performance in Australia and the US, which are major drivers of February’s 25% revenue downgrade and the exits of both the UK and US CEOs.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

In our view, the limitations of the upfront model are being laid bare and the addressable market is proving much smaller than initially hoped. With slowing growth and accelerating cash burn we believe the group risks being forced to raise additional equity {at a significant discount to last summer’s 360p raise} or reduce marketing spend and abandon the Australian and US operations.

BE11:25am

A reminder that Purplebricks is on on 2.2x 2020 EV/sales and doesn't break even on EBITDA on any reasonable forecast range.

Tom Dalgleish Australian residential RE is dire with a Labor Govt likely to make it worse
BE11:25am

● Running out of steam in the UK: After rapid growth in the three years
following its launch, Purplebricks has stagnated. Listing growth in the past
18 months has been negligible, resulting in significant revenue
downgrades in the UK business. In our view, this reflects the fundamental
flaws in the model and reduced size of the addressable market relative to
earlier expectations. Data commissioned by the company indicates that
just 60% of Purplebricks’ paying customers completed their sale in FY
2018, leaving c40% out of pocket. As traditional agency fees come down
and Purplebricks raises prices, the potential savings on offer narrow
skewing the implied risk/reward to the downside.
● Challenges Down Under and in the US: Purplebricks’ international
expansion was supposed to pave the way for the next leg of growth. So far,
the group has managed to spend £65m on marketing to achieve c11,000
instructions and £90m of losses, while also losing two regional CEOs. The
weak Australian housing market is placing pressure on the upfront fee
model and Purplebricks is rapidly losing what little share of the listings
market it had. Meanwhile, weak trading in the US has forced the group to
abandon the fixed-fee model in favour of a no-sale, no-fee strategy. We
expect combined losses of £53m this year.
● Current cash burn £7m/month; additional equity or debt required:
Reduced growth in the UK and accelerated losses in the US and Australia
have combined to deliver £23.5m of negative FCF in the past 12 months and
the group’s net cash position is reducing by c£7m each month. Without a
significant change in the current strategy, we expect losses and cash burn
to accelerate this year and in 2020, when we believe the group will face the
choice of either raising fresh equity, or debt; or retrenching to the UK.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

So, a little context here.

BE11:26am

It's a change of analyst. To Sam Cullen.

BE11:27am

Who until last year was at Jefferies. Mike Prew's property team.

JimboRock small fry but perhaps... K3 Capital Group PLC (LON:K3C)
11:28 am
BE11:28am

The rest of his sector calls look like this.

BE11:28am

● Countrywide (Buy) – Darkest before the dawn: After a period of sustained
mismanagement, we believe Countrywide’s shares are investible again. Although
recent performance has been extremely poor, many of the wounds were selfinflicted. With a new management team and a refreshed, but reassuringly simple,
strategy in place, we feel the risk/reward dynamic is skewed to the upside.
● Foxtons (Hold) – Struggling to out-fox the market: Affordability constraints
means Foxtons’ major market, London, remains extremely challenging. We think
there is only limited momentum in the short term, but a recovery will lead to rapid
EPS momentum.
● LSL (Hold) – Steady as she goes: A decentralised management style has delivered
sector-leading performance in recent years as the group benefited from its
decentralised management style, which is a trend we expect to continue.

BE11:36am

GVC’s Q1 trading update confirms that the group has had a solid
start to the year. Q1 net gaming revenue (NGR) rose by 8%, albeit
the pace of growth has moderated in recent weeks (the January-
February period increased by 11%). Either way, the statement is
a reminder that the group is enjoying decent trading momentum
after a tumultuous period for the stock. Our sense is that there is
modest upside risk to current consensus estimates (our forecasts
are modestly higher, +1.5%). Its performance is at odds with the
current valuation, albeit there are clearly multiple reasons (stock
and sector specific) to explain the valuation disconnect at present.

BE11:37am

And Citi.

kemche How about listing some of the unlisted stuff on Nex or even Jersey or some other liquid exchange to circumvent certain restrictions - that would be a hoot
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Citi's Take — GVC reported a good 1Q19 trading update, with group NGR (+9% ex FX) showing some slowdown since Jan-Feb due to unfavourable win margins in the UK and Italy end of February and March (see detail below). However, management comments that volume trends were good across all major online brands and territories. The board is confident in delivering 2019e EBITDA in-line with expectations (EBITDA: Company-compiled consensus: £648m, Citi: £663m).
 March showed some deceleration due to win margin contraction vs. 1 Jan – 24 Feb — 1Q19 Group NGR +9% ex FX (Jan-Feb: +11%), Online NGR +18% (Jan-Feb: +22% vs. Citi +17% in 2019e) driven by sports brands NGR +17% and games brands NGR +20%. European retail NGR +3% impacted by a weak win margin - 1.8pp yoy, with sports wagers +13% (Jan-Feb: +9%) and UK retail LFL NGR flat (Jan-Feb: -2%), with the weak win margin (-1.1pp) offset by recycling (flat wagers).
All 1Q19 revenue growth numbers given excluding FX.
 2019 Outlook — We do not expect any major changes to consensus after 1Q19 results and currently forecast 2019 adj. EBITDA £663m, 2% above consensus at £648m (consensus source: GVC).
 Implications — We do not expect any material share price reaction to this trading update.

Viking1 Kiwi Juice absolutely , however Other parties might join
BE11:38am

And Goldman.

BE11:38am

While online NGR trends came slightly lower than the Jan/Feb trends reported with the full-year results, we expect the numbers to be taken positively given the recent de-rating of the share price. GVC continues to deliver strong volume driven growth of its online business which we believe is not reflected in the current valuation. We remain Buy rated on the name, though the multiple could remain under pressure for some time post the recent share sale by management and a board member.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

And Barclays.

BE11:38am

A brief statement met with brief thoughts: 1) March win margins were clearly very soft in the UK (we flagged this here: Starting to address self-regulation, 3/4/19). Italy win margins were soft too. FX would have been a headwind in March too. Combining these two factors (both out of the company’s control) NGR growth in March slowed. By now this should not be a surprise to the market but it could be seen as a negative by some. 2) Comps are tough going forward (the World Cup is likely to have had a 2-4% NGR benefit post substitution), so as GVC annualizes that event, growth will slow. That said, our estimates (and Bloomberg consensus) seem to have more than factored that in (see table below where our FY19 estimates imply online NGR slows from +17% to +9% in Q2-4 19). If anything after such a strong start, we see scope for upgrades in H2 from stronger than expected top line growth. This coupled with a c. 40% contribution margin online and strong cost control (note staff are incentivsed on EBITDA) means operational gearing could be in evidence in H219 (halting the run of regulation driven downgrades. 3) The whistle to whistle advertising ban could be EBITDA positive for GVC in H219 so we see scope for a c. £10m opex-driven EBITDA upgrade in H2 19 too. 4) Finally, Retail trading was strong in March. GVC trades on a CY20 P/E of 8.2x, a FCF Yield of 11.5% and a dividend yield of 7%. It is a cheap share. That said sentiment towards the shares and the sector is low (in part due to the recent share sales of the CEO/Chairman) and the Capital Markets Day in May is important to highlight group diversification, views on self-regulation and US clarity. GVC is still our preferred name in the European gambling sector as we see it as the only company likely to deliver earnings momentum in 2019.

BE11:39am

I feel that's comprehensive enough for the stock's ~1% move.

11:38 am
undefined
BE11:39am

Hammerson -- also mentioned -- is Stifel.

Hammerson PLC (HMSO:LSE): Last: 335.30, down 12.3 (-3.54%), High: 342.60, Low: 329.30, Volume: 2.36m
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Simple enough. Disposals are going to dilute earnings and, absent further information, there's no reason to think that the truce with Elliott will result in value for any shareholder other than Elliott.

BE11:41am

Hammerson's strategy as it faces the hard reality of falling Retail asset valuations, at least in the UK, has been to (1) commit to sell a further £500m+ of assets this year, (2) the establishment of an investment committee to oversee the disposals, and (3) reach an agreement with Elliott Advisors, whereby the latter will not increase its voting and economic interests over the next 12 months.
We do not think this will be sufficient to arrest the decline in the shares, with (1) EPS falling as a result of disposals, (2) an investment committee which we think has been established to shield the executive from criticism if/when disposals are well below book, and (3) the 4th largest shareholder striking bilateral deals with the company, the details of which do not seem to have been shared.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Berenberg wrote this at the back end of last month.

BE11:52am

Growth in agriculture has decelerated, and could be at risk if increases in
meat consumption slow: Bayer has the best seeds asset in the world.
However, the incremental returns on improving yield for farmers have
fallen markedly on lower crop prices over the past five years, and we doubt
that Monsanto would today be trading near the c15x EV/EBITDA that Bayer
paid for it. Moreover, the global seeds industry is a victim of its own success.
Corn and soybean account for over 70% of the industry’s sales value, and
demand for both is primarily driven by animal feed. US yields for both have
increased by more than 30% over the past two decades and the end-stocks
are at near record highs. This will not change much in the near-term.
● There is also a risk to demand: European total meat consumption has not
grown since the late 1980s; change in global diets may thus pose a risk. We
have run scenarios for corn and soybean demand based on potential trends
such as slowing growth in meat consumption. While agriculture’s nearterm
top-line growth should be close to the 4% guided, if the world
switches to European-style stagnation/decline, this growth could be 2% or
even close to 0% post-2030.
● Leverage a problem, and exacerbates issues with pharma: Bayer has by
far the cheapest two-year PEG ratio of peers, but its leverage remains high.
As per its own guidance, Bayer will finish 2019 with flat net debt and over
3x net debt/EBITDA ex-glyphosate payouts. In the absence of cuts to the
dividend or a rights issue, it is difficult to see how it will be able to de-lever
to a level with which investors feel comfortable in the near term. On our
estimates, it may need to spend an additional EUR220m pa on R&D to
compensate for the Xarelto and Eylea patent expiries from 2024.
● Valuation: Bayer trades on 8x 2019 EV/EBITDA and enjoys a secure twoyear
EPS CAGR of c8%. However, if we include EUR10bn of potential
glyphosate-related liabilities in its EV, the multiple is a less remarkable 9x,
broadly in line with the European chemicals sector.

Chuck Norris Any Grand National tips from Shrewdette?

Kiwi-juice The Bayer story is interesting on how markets work. As the shares go down, everything gets gloomier and arguments become more and more specious. An example: If the animal feed farmers don't plant animal feed seeds anymore, they will plant other seeds, also sold by Bayer. So no loss in growth by Americans eating less meat.
